clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Adding Subcutaneous Long-acting Glargine to Insulin Drip Therapy Compared With Standard Insulin Drip Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of a Subcutaneously Administered Long-acting Insulin Added to Insulin Drip Therapy as Compared With Standard Insulin Drip Treatment

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators anticipate that the use of Glargine will decrease the duration of an insulin drip, the dose of short-acting insulin in the drip, hospital and ICU (intensive care unit) length of stay, improve glycemic control, and prevent rebound hyperglycemias when the insulin drip is discontinued.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction in rebound hyperglycemia (blood glucose levels over 180 mg/dl)

secondary_outcome.measure: Reduction in duration of insulin drip therapy and reduction in total and average per hour insulin drip dose
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within one week of insulin drip therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Reduction in ICU length of stay
Reduction in time to get back to control of glycemia (140-180 mg/dl) if rebound hyperglycemia occurs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within one week post insulin drip

arm_group.description: Insulin drip and glargine 0.25 units per kg body weight

intervention.description: Glargine 0.25 units per kg body weight given every 24 hours while patients are receiving intravenous (IV) standard insulin drip therapy

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperglycemic hyperosmolar non-ketotic states, hyperglycemia with severe illness, pre- and postoperative states, nothing by mouth (NPO), as well as gastric (tube feeding) and parenteral nutrition requiring insulin drip.
- Patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) will be included.
- Patients with both types of diabetes will be among those treated with the insulin drip while being NPO, having severe concomitant illness or receiving enteral and parenteral nutrition.
- Patients will be of age 19 to 80.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to consent for the study for any reason including cognitive impairment secondary to hyperglycemia, presence of severe medical conditions requiring intubation, severe sepsis, hypothermia, and anticipated length of insulin drip 2 weeks and longer, pregnancy, Lantus allergy, and concurrent sulfonamide treatment
